Knowledge Point: In the formation of a question, Ik \isi{interrogative} pronouns fill the same slot as the nouns they are representing. It is common for the \isi{interrogative} pronoun to be ‘fronted’: moved for emphasis to the first place in the sentence. When this happens, the \isi{interrogative} pronoun takes the \isi{copulative case} (see \sectref{sec:7.8}), as exemplified in sentences \REF{ex:pro:1}-\REF{ex:pro:2}. Both demonstrated word orders are perfectly acceptable. For more on how questions are formed in Ik, please see \sectref{sec:10.4.3}.

As shown in examples \REF{ex:pro:3}-\REF{ex:pro:4}, no matter where an Ik \isi{relative clause} (\textsc{rc}) appears in a sentence, the \isi{relative pronoun} will introduce it as the first element in the clause. The entity in the \isi{main clause} that the \isi{relative clause} is modifying – called the \textsc{common argument} – must be the last word before the \isi{relative clause}. As a \isi{clitic}, the \isi{relative pronoun} attaches to the \isi{common argument}. To learn more about the syntax of relative clauses, please see \sectref{sec:10.3.2}.

These \isi{reflexive} pronouns are used extensively to make \textsc{semi-transitive} verbs: verbs falling between transitive and \isi{intransitive}. For example, while the verb ídzòn ‘to discharge, emit’ is \isi{intransitive} and the verb ídzès ‘to discharge, emit, shoot’ is transitive, the verb \textit{ídzesa as{\Í}} ‘to shoot across (literally `to shoot -self’)’ is ‘semi-transitive’ because the subject and object of the shooting are the same entity.
